author: By Marina Harss
title: In Miami, Climbing Ballet’s Everest: ‘Swan Lake’
description: It has taken Miami City Ballet six years to get the Alexei Ratmansky production — the biggest and most expensive in the company’s history — off the ground.
content: MIAMI — “Will this bird ever land?” Lourdes Lopez, the artistic director of Miami City Ballet, said in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Slurping Noodles
description: A husband and wife disagree about how culturally appropriate it is for a white American.
content: Nash writes: I slurp my noodles, even spaghetti. It’s the best way to eat them, and culturally appropriate in certain contexts. My wife says it’s improper — and inappropriate for me, a white American, to slurp outside very narrow circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Shauntel Lowe
title: W.N.B.A. Raises $75 Million With Hopes of Business Model Revamp
description: Cathy Engelbert, the league’s commissioner, said the investment could help fund marketing, improve digital products and fan outreach to increase revenue.
content: The W.N.B.A. has raised $75 million from more than two dozen investors in a bid to revamp its business model as players call for expansion, higher salaries and better benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek, Emily Cochrane and Lananh Nguyen
title: Biden’s Pick for Top Bank Cop Faces Narrow Path to Confirmation
description: Sarah Bloom Raskin, the White House’s nominee to lead bank supervision at the Federal Reserve, is under fire for her views on climate regulation.
content: Sarah Bloom Raskin’s past statements on climate regulation are stoking heated Republican opposition to her nomination to be the Federal Reserve’s vice chair for supervision and could leave President Biden’s pick with a narrow path to confirmation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: It slices, it dices: It’s an Alpine ski.
description: An analyst on USA’s broadcast coverage cut through fruit to demonstrate how dangerously sharp the edge of a ski can be. The skier Ted Ligety joined in, sabering open a champagne bottle.
content: For a moment on Wednesday night, USA Network’s broadcast of Alpine skiing looked more like a cooking segment than a sporting event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Military developments in Eastern Europe.
content: President Biden has approved the deployment of about 3,000 additional U.S. troops to Eastern Europe to reassure NATO allies anxious over tensions surrounding Ukraine. The troops, which include 1,000 already in Germany, will head to Poland and Romania, according to the Pentagon. The U.S. has said it will not deploy troops to Ukraine in the event of a conflict there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Artistically in Sync, and Reunited for ‘The Merchant of Venice’
description: Arin Arbus and John Douglas Thompson are collaborating on their fifth play, a Theater for a New Audience production that begins previews Saturday.
content: More than 25 years later, John Douglas Thompson still remembers the summer heat that made him sweat beneath his costume. He remembers lines, too, that have been stored in his brain ever since — like the “Hath not a Jew eyes” speech, in which his character, the moneylender Shylock, asserts his own humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘And Just Like That,’ the Show Is Over
description: In an interview, creators of the “Sex and the City” revival discuss the show’s reception, middle-age miseries and why Chris Noth was edited out of the season finale.
content: The interview includes mild spoilers for the season finale of “And Just Like That. …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: There’s a New Surveillance State. It’s Your Neighbor.
description: Some so-called leaders are exhorting Americans to turn in and against one another.
content: The citizens of Virginia have been called to battle. They’ve been shown the enemy. They’ve been armed — not with physical weapons, but with an email address where they can send reports of anything suspicious that they see in their children’s schools, anything they deem disrespectful in their children’s classrooms, anything in a teacher’s or administrator’s conduct that rankles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: The Post Office Is Buying Gas-Powered Trucks, Despite Biden Climate Order
description: The president wants an electric federal fleet, but Postmaster Louis DeJoy is spending billions on gas-powered vehicles. That’s prompted scrutiny and calls for his resignation.
content: WASHINGTON — A senior House Democrat called on Wednesday for the resignation of Louis DeJoy, the postmaster general, saying he flouted President Biden’s plan to electrify the federal fleet by placing a multibillion-dollar order for mostly gasoline-powered vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Was He Really Having a Heart Attack?
description: The doctor insisted he was — but he felt it couldn’t be true. One of them was right.
content: The 67-year-old man dropped heavily into the plastic chair inside the Alta Mountain resort in Utah. It was his third day skiing the Rockies but his first at Alta. He had been excited to try these new slopes, but his run that morning was brutal. It was a clear, cold day, and the sharp mountain edges stood out crisply before the bright blue sky, so different from the slopes back East where he lived and usually skied. About halfway down an intermediate-grade slope on his first run that morning, the man started to feel bad, as if he were coming down with something. He rested for a few minutes and when that didn’t help, headed back to the lodge. The trip down was miserable. He felt a strange exhaustion and had to stop every few minutes, as if he were running up the mountain rather than skiing down. It was so bad that, at one point, he worried he would have to be taken in by the ski patrol. But he made it. Finally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Mitski Steps Back Into the Darkness
description: On her new album, “Laurel Hell,” the singer-songwriter delves into electronics and ambivalence.
content: “Let’s step carefully into the dark,” Mitski sings to begin her new album, “Laurel Hell,” and continues, “Once we’re in I’ll remember my way around.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The Bank of England raises rates again to combat rapidly rising prices.
description: The central bank raised its benchmark rate, a second time in two consecutive meetings, in a move it called “necessary” to tame inflation.
content: Inflation in Britain has been rising relentlessly, and the Bank of England made an assertive move on Thursday to tamp it down: its first back-to-back interest rate increases at policy-setting meetings in more than 17 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Living With the Virus
description: Denmark, and a host of other countries, are beginning to treat Covid as an endemic threat.
content: More governments across the world are saying they’re ready to “live with the virus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Is Biden’s Strategy With Putin Working, or Goading Moscow to War?
description: The Biden administration’s goal is to cut the Russians off at each turn by exposing their plans. But Russian President Vladimir V. Putin says that approach could spark a conflict.
content: WASHINGTON — At key moments since the Ukraine crisis flared into the headlines two months ago, President Biden and his aides have worked to expose Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s plans, declassifying intelligence about his next steps and calling him out as an “aggressor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: Amazon confronts pandemic costs and raises the price of Prime.
description: Revenue rose to a record $137.4 billion, just slightly under forecasts.
content: An improving economy and a persistent virus are beginning to weigh on Amazon’s retail business, even as its cloud computing business grew and an investment lifted profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: A Fox News ‘Defector’ on How the Network ‘Played Footsie’ With Trump
description: Jonah Goldberg explains why he left the broadcaster and its changing relationship with conservatism.
content: The former Fox commentator Jonah Goldberg — who has been called a “Fox defector” — says that Tucker Carlson’s latest documentary series was “the anvil that broke the camel’s back.” Titled “Patriot Purge,” it featured conspiracy theories about the Jan. 6 insurrection under the guise of journalistic interrogation. It also became a breaking point in a schism unfolding at the network between those who have embraced the Big Lie and those who feel troubled by the network’s abandonment of basic facts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Brianna Decker, a U.S. hockey star, is out for the rest of the Beijing Games.
description: Her injury is a harsh blow to American ambitions to repeat as Olympic champions.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Teenager Tracked Elon Musk’s Jet on Twitter. Then Came the Direct Message.
description: Jack Sweeney, a freshman at the University of Central Florida, said that Mr. Musk raised privacy and security concerns about his popular Twitter account, @ElonJet.
content: For Elon Musk, the billionaire chief executive of Tesla and founder of SpaceX, traveling by private jet is not such a private endeavor.

title: A Choice Board for Eight STEM Projects You Can Do With Any Newspaper

content: Featured Choice Board: Eight STEM Projects You Can Do With Any Newspaper

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Medicare Will Soon Provide Free At-Home Coronavirus Tests
description: The announcement came after lawmakers and advocates argued that Medicare recipients had been passed over in the push to require insurers to cover the tests.
content: Medicare, which covers roughly 60 million Americans, will provide free over-the-counter rapid coronavirus tests beginning in the spring, according to the federal government’s Medicare and Medicaid agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Trachta
title: ‘And Just Like That’ Season Finale Recap: Stiletto on the Other Foot
description: Carrie and Miranda trade places. And some burning questions are put to rest, along with the ashes of an all-consuming love.
content: “I can stay here and write about my life, or I can go with him and live my life!”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Film Club: ‘How To Run a TikTok-Famous Bodega’
description: What are the local business that make your town special?
content: “How To Run a TikTok-Famous Bodega” is a 13-minute video from a new Times series, “On the Job With Priya Krishna.” It profiles Rahim Mohamed who manages a bodega in Red Hook, Brooklyn and has become a TikTok star with more than two million followers watching him come up with wild sandwich combinations for his never-ending stream of customers. If you visited Mr. Mohamed’s bodega, what sandwich would you ask to be made the “Ocky way”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: U.S. Overcomes Honduras, the Cold and Some Doubts
description: After losing to Canada and coming under withering criticism, the team rebounded with a win over Honduras and a goal from the substitute Christian Pulisic.
content: Perhaps no moment better exemplified the mounting pressure — and its slight alleviation — on the United States men’s national soccer team than the one that occurred in the 67th minute on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: As Texas braces for a cold snap, officials promise the power grid will hold.
description: The state hopes to avoid a repeat of the catastrophic winter storm last February that killed more than 200 people.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Nearly a year after a catastrophic winter storm led to sweeping power outages and left more than 200 people dead, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas reassured the state’s 29 million residents on Thursday that the power grid was expected to hold despite freezing temperatures across a large swath of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Rikki Novetsky, Sydney Harper, Asthaa Chaturvedi, M.J. Davis Lin, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Dan Powell
title: Is ISIS Back on the Rise?
description: Three years after the United States declared victory over the Islamic State, a well-organized attack in northern Syria is raising questions.
content: A recent ISIS attack on a prison in northeastern Syria became the biggest confrontation between the terrorist group and the United States and its allied forces since 2019. The attack raises a question: Could the Islamic State group be on the cusp of a resurgence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Bill Fitch, Who Coached Celtics to the ’81 Title, Is Dead at 89
description: Hailed for reviving sagging teams, he was voted one of the top 10 coaches in the N.B.A.’s first half century and was twice named coach of the year.
content: Bill Fitch, who gained a reputation for reviving the fortunes of dismal N.B.A. teams and took the Boston Celtics to the 1981 league championship in a pro coaching career spanning 25 seasons, died on Wednesday in Lake Conroe, Texas, north of Houston. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Dune’ and ‘The Power of the Dog’ Lead BAFTA Nominees
description: Dennis Villeneuve’s sci-fi epic and Jane Campion’s western secured the most nominations in a lineup notable for its diversity.
content: LONDON — The unpredictability of this year’s award season continued on Thursday when the nominees were announced for this year’s EE British Academy Film Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix, hoping to keep viewers at home, reveals its 2022 film lineup.
description: Netflix said it would release 61 English-language, live-action films in 2022, as well as five animated features, three anime films and 17 live-action movies in other languages.
content: At a time when the future of theatergoing remains very much in question, Netflix revealed a film lineup for 2022 that is again chock-full of A-list stars and directors, giving viewers plenty of reasons to watch movies at home.
source.name: The New York Times

description: It seems that nothing — neither the pandemic nor the shadow of doping scandals nor concerns over China’s human rights record — will deter the International Olympic Committee from staging the Beijing Games.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.

author: By Annie Karni
title: Clyburn Pushes His Pick for Supreme Court, Testing His Sway With Biden
description: The highest-ranking Black member of Congress is credited with helping resurrect the president’s 2020 campaign at a critical point. Now he is calling in a favor.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina was already picturing Judge J. Michelle Childs sitting on the Supreme Court bench in early 2020 when he suggested Joseph R. Biden Jr. could revive his faltering presidential campaign by pledging to nominate the first Black woman to serve there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Feb. 9, 2022
description: What do people think, by country, about whether the world is becoming a better or worse place with each generation? Who is more optimistic — young adults or adults?
content: This graph shows how young adults, ages 15 to 24 years old, and adults, ages 40 or older, responded to the question: “Do you think the world is becoming a better or worse place with each generation?” The data is from a survey of more than 21,000 people from 21 countries who are part of nationally representative samples from all regions of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Top Aides to Boris Johnson Quit, Adding to Downing Street Turmoil
description: Day after day, new developments add to the political crisis over boozy parties during lockdown, which threatens to bring down the prime minister.
content: LONDON — An exodus of senior officials from 10 Downing Street on Thursday deepened the crisis engulfing Prime Minister Boris Johnson, as he fought to hold on to power in the wake of a scandal over get-togethers that breached lockdown restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: British home energy prices are set to rise 54%.
description: The jump in heat and electric bills, a result of the record rise in natural gas prices, will be “extremely worrying for many people,” a regulator said.
content: The price many British households pay for their heat and electricity is set to rise by 54 percent in April, the government’s energy regulator, Ofgem, said Thursday. The big jump, caused mainly by a surge of global natural gas prices, is expected to exacerbate concerns over inflation and the cost of living in Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Meta plunges and sets off Wall Street’s worst drop in nearly a year.
description: Shares of Meta, the parent company of Facebook, fell more than 26 percent, a loss that wiped more than $230 billion off its market value.
content: Stocks on Wall Street tumbled on Thursday, with Meta, the parent company of Facebook, leading the way with a drop of 26.4 percent, its worst one-day loss ever and one that erased more than $230 billion off its market value.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: How to Cook to Feel Good
description: Tofu curry, garlic rasam and dumpling soup deserve a spot in your rotation.
content: I loved Yewande Komolafe’s most recent column about the foods she makes when the floorboards start to feel cold under her feet, and she wants to feel warm and nourished by the food she cooks. She calls this big family of broths, soups and teas her “restoratives” and builds them quickly, from simple ingredients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: Sheila Heti Is Still Asking Questions
description: She has written about some of our biggest modern-day conundrums: whether to have children, how to live an authentic life. With her new novel, “Pure Colour,” she considers how love and art can heal.
content: In her poignant and imaginative new novel, “Pure Colour,” Sheila Heti opens with an unusual concept: Humans are bears, fish or birds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shell’s profit jumps, riding higher prices for oil and natural gas.
description: Europe’s largest energy company said it would use some of the earnings to buy back more shares and increase its dividend.
content: Booming prices for oil and natural gas propelled Shell’s profit in the fourth quarter of 2021, lifting its adjusted earnings to $6.39 billion, up from $393 million a year earlier, the company reported Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Much Do I Really Owe My Family?
description: A reader wonders whether he is obligated to cover repairs on a house purchased by his ailing father and his unreliable brother.
content: My father is retired and lives outside the country. He bought a house here with my brother; it’s in both of their names and mostly paid off. Because my brother has never been able to support himself, though, the house has fallen into disrepair. Now, my father is coming home temporarily for cancer treatment and has asked me to fix up the house so he can stay in it. I have offered to pay for a smaller place for him (without my brother), but he wants to stay in their house — possibly so my brother has a place to live. I don’t think it’s fair for me to pay for repairs on a house that my brother can’t maintain. What can I do without damaging my relationships?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robin Herman, Who Pried Open Doors in the N.H.L., Dies at 70
description: When hockey teams barred female reporters from men’s locker rooms, she pushed back, breaking through a barrier and campaigning successfully for equal access for women.
content: Robin Herman, who as a hockey reporter for The New York Times broke a gender barrier when she became one of the first female journalists to enter a men’s professional sports locker room in North America, died on Tuesday at her home in Waltham, Mass. She was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Greer
title: A Leader Who Defies Easy Political Labeling. Finally.
description: What makes Mayor Eric Adams of New York hard to pin down is what makes him so interesting.
content: Many Black Americans have a friend or relative like Eric Adams, the new mayor of New York. We have uncles who bring up the progressive benefits of Black Lives Matter in the same breath as the conservative talking points about Black-on-Black crime. We have relatives who are cops or former cops who do not want the police defunded nor loved ones stopped, frisked and mistreated by officers. We have friends who are deeply suspicious of the system and come up with their own ways to deal with it — in Mr. Adams’s case, proposing that his brother head up his security operation to keep him safe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Islamic State has shown that it can still pull off military operations.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon — One week after Islamic State fighters attacked a prison in northeastern Syria, where they have held out despite a heavy assault by a Kurdish-led militia backed by the United States, the terrorist organization published its version of what had gone down.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — One week after Islamic State fighters attacked a prison in northeastern Syria, where they have held out despite a heavy assault by a Kurdish-led militia backed by the United States, the terrorist organization published its version of what had gone down.

title: Is Taking the SAT a Necessary Step in Preparing for Post-High School Life?

content: What do you know or what have you heard about the SAT? Have you taken the test, or will you take it someday?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Waters
title: Cremation Borrows a Page From the Direct-to-Consumer Playbook
description: With names like Solace, Tulip and Eirene, start-ups are hoping to make cremation the next big at-home purchase.
content: Less than two hours after you book a cremation with Eirene, a start-up in Ontario, the company dispatches a mortuary transit driver to pick up your loved one. The body is ferried to a cold storage facility, where it stays until Eirene has processed the end-of-life paperwork. From there, one of Eirene’s crematory partners will cremate the body, and a funeral director who works for Eirene will either drive the ashes to your door or send them via mail. All told, the process takes about one week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: One Illness Reminds Democrats They Have No Votes to Spare
description: With a Supreme Court confirmation vote approaching, some Democrats are urging a speedier process to guard against unforeseen circumstances.
content: WASHINGTON — It was the troubling development that Democrats holding a precarious 50-50 Senate majority had long been dreading: One of their colleagues suffered a serious medical episode, leaving them one vote short of a majority with a Supreme Court confirmation vote on the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: Could Detroit Become the Next Fashion City?
description: In bringing an exhibition of creative talent to New York, the fashion label Deviate wants to show that Detroit has more to offer than a quick hit of novelty for luxury giants.
content: “I think our landlord is like, ‘What are you guys doing?’” said Cassidy Tucker, sitting alongside her sister Kelsey on a Zoom call from their Detroit studio last week. Surrounding them was a pileup of 50 pieces of original artwork, with several 8-foot-by-4-foot mural-like sculptures meant to approximate the pages of a giant storybook. The art was to be squeezed into the 26-foot truck they’d rented to haul the lot from Detroit to New York City for an exhibition called “Don’t Sleep on Detroit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Rejected Mail Ballots Are Showing Racial Disparities
description: Auditors in Washington State found that the mail ballots of Black voters were being rejected at four times the rate of white voters. Similar trends have been seen in other states.
content: SEATTLE — Among the thousands of mail-in ballots that were rejected in Washington State during the 2020 election, auditors have found that the votes of Black residents were thrown out four times as often as those of white voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Calvocoressi and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: She Ties My Bow Tie
description: Love poems can be hard to read. But this one by Gabrielle Calvocoressi charms because of its delicate intimacy.
content: I find love poems hard to write (and to read) because they can so easily teeter on the edge of sentimentality. I much prefer the conflagration of a good breakup poem. But this poem by Gabrielle Calvocoressi charms me because of its delicate intimacy. The second person “you” in the first line and throughout the poem invites the reader into a private relationship. The poem, in its sonnetlike compression, makes arguments about the miniature motions of love during a simple act of tying a bow tie, as if to say that describing love is easiest through the acts of love. Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Jackass Forever’ Review: A Visit From the Goon Squad
description: Sharp cinematography and enviable camaraderie continue to hoist Johnny Knoxville and friends above their many imitators in this deceptively kindhearted sequel.
content: The Jackass guys have gotten older but, thankfully, their maturity levels have stayed the same. Over 22 years, three television seasons and movies on screens big and small, Johnny Knoxville’s lovable goons have been whacked so often that their orchestra of moans could play “O Fortuna.”
source.name: The New York Times

content: BUSTER KEATONA Filmmaker’s LifeBy James Curtis

title: California’s Snowpack Plummets After a Very Dry January
description: The gains of an extremely wet December have been muted by an unusually dry January.
content: For anyone tracking the state of California’s drought, the past four months have delivered an emotional whiplash.

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Janet Mead, Nun Whose Pop-Rock Hymn Reached the Top of the Charts, Dies
description: Her upbeat version of “The Lord’s Prayer” was an instant hit in Australia, reached No. 4 in the U.S. and was nominated for a Grammy (it lost to Elvis Presley).
content: Sister Janet Mead, an Australian nun whose crystalline voice carried her to the upper reaches of the charts in the 1970s with a pop-rock version of “The Lord’s Prayer,” died on Jan. 26 in Adelaide. She was in her early 80s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: This Jack Reacher Is Going to Be Big
description: Fans of the Reacher books were underwhelmed when Tom Cruise was picked to play the hulking hero in two movies. A new series, and Alan Ritchson, may remedy that.
content: Jack Reacher is one popular action hero. Hatched by the British writer Lee Child, Reacher has so far righted wrongs in 26 novels and a slew of short stories; the books have collectively sold more 100 million copies worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Memos Show Roots of Trump’s Focus on Jan. 6 and Alternate Electors
description: Just over two weeks after Election Day, lawyers working with the Trump campaign set out a rationale for creating alternate slates of electors as part of an effort to buy time to overturn the results.
content: Fifteen days after Election Day in 2020, James R. Troupis, a lawyer for the Trump campaign in Wisconsin, received a memo setting out what became the rationale for an audacious strategy: to put in place alternate slates of electors in states where President Donald J. Trump was trying to overturn his loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Brian X. Chen
title: A Change by Apple Is Tormenting Internet Companies, Especially Meta
description: Meta’s stock prices plunged after the company reported that Apple’s privacy features would cost it billions this year. It’s not the only tech giant to take a hit.
content: Apple’s vision of a more private web is not necessarily a more profitable one for internet companies that depend on advertising revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: One Day in the ‘Parallel Universe’ of a London I.C.U.
description: Quotation of the day for Thursday, February 3, 2022.
content: “You know, in Wave 1, we were heroes. By Wave 2, we were the enemy. And that’s hard.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: ‘Joined at the Hip’: Jeff Zucker’s Relationship With a Top CNN Executive
description: Allison Gollust, an executive vice president, has worked alongside Mr. Zucker for two decades. He cited their relationship as he abruptly resigned.
content: Jeff Zucker’s tenure as president of CNN ended in an abrupt fashion on Wednesday just days after he acknowledged to company lawyers what had long been rumored in television news circles: He was in a romantic relationship with the person he has described as his closest professional colleague, Allison Gollust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: A Jewish Teacher Criticized Israel. She Was Fired.
description: Jessie Sander had just started a job at a synagogue in Scarsdale. But then a blog post she had written was found.
content: Last summer, Jessie Sander had been on the job at a Jewish school in Westchester County for less than a month when a meeting with her boss took an unexpected turn. Was she comfortable working at a Zionist institution? he asked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Teenagers in The Times: January 2022
description: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
content: Here is the January edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. We publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford earned $17.9 billion in 2021, bolstered by a large gain on its Rivian stake.
description: Ford ended the year with more revenue than General Motors for the second year in a row.
content: Ford Motor said on Thursday that it made a hefty profit in 2021 because of a big gain on its holding in a fledgling electric-vehicle maker and higher production in the second half of last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: Chicago Officer Who Killed Laquan McDonald Leaves Prison Early
description: Jason Van Dyke served three years of a nearly seven-year sentence. He was convicted of second-degree murder in the teenager’s death, which put a spotlight on police misconduct.
content: CHICAGO — When Jason Van Dyke, a former Chicago police officer, was convicted in 2018 of the murder of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald, some Chicagoans saw a promise of justice: Mr. Van Dyke would serve time in prison for shooting the Black teenager 16 times, an act that was captured on a dashboard camera and widely viewed by the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Leon Kossoff: Looking at Life With a Loaded Brush
description: A 13-painting show surveys a great career and marks the publication of a catalog of all the artist’s paintings of family, friends and London in a single, weighty volume.
content: During his decades as an artist, the British painter Leon Kossoff (1926-2019) produced 510 known oil paintings. This can be said because they have all been tracked down and published in a catalogue raisonné just out from Modern Art Press (London).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: On the eve of his meeting with Xi, Putin pledges to deepen ties with China.
description: Russia’s president did not mention Ukraine, but said he and China’s leader would coordinate foreign policy “based on close and coinciding approaches.”
content: BEIJING — Ahead of his visit to Beijing for the opening of the Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pledged on Thursday to deepen his country’s diplomatic and economic ties with China in ways that would counter American power and influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel McGraw
title: Snow shut down parts of Cleveland last month. Residents hope to avoid more disruption.
description: The Ohio city is no stranger to winter weather, but it was bracing for a potentially record amount of snow.
content: CLEVELAND — Grocery shoppers did what grocery shoppers often do as a major snowstorm bore down on the Great Lakes: They bought a little extra, just in case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The N.F.L.’s Race Problem
description: Most of its players are Black. Only one head coach is.
content: Second and even third chances are not that unusual for N.F.L. head coaches. Over their careers, several coaches have run three different teams, and most of them had only mixed records of success before getting the third job. If they had excelled in one of the earlier two jobs, after all, they might have still had it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Rotterdam May Dismantle Part of Bridge for Jeff Bezos’ Superyacht
description: The Dutch city of Rotterdam walked back earlier comments that the historic Koningshaven Bridge would be briefly dismantled. On Thursday, officials said a decision had not yet been made.
content: The Dutch city of Rotterdam on Thursday walked back plans to dismantle part of the historic Koningshaven Bridge so that a superyacht built for Amazon’s founder, Jeff Bezos, could pass through the city’s river, saying that a decision had not yet been made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: ‘I Wanted That Self-Reliance Back’: Disabled Hikers Forge a New Path
description: Outdoor enthusiasts with disabilities are pushing to encounter nature on their own terms, with self-written guides, better equipment and even guide dogs trained for the backcountry.
content: Beneath the wooden boardwalk where Syren Nagakyrie, 40, was on a hike through Lettuce Lake Conservation Park in Tampa, Fla., dark shadows of fish moved in the vegetation-clogged waters, while red-eyed herons strode between the cypress roots that stuck out from the water like knobby, twisted knees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Jones
title: Body Odor May Smell Worse to You Than Your Ancient Ancestors
description: Researchers worked out which receptors in your nose detect particular scent molecules, and found evidence of evolutionary change in some of these genes.
content: When you take a whiff of something, odor molecules sail inside your nose where they bind to proteins — called olfactory receptors — on cells that line your nasal cavity. These receptors trigger signals that your brain interprets as one or many smells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Lawsuit Against Live Nation Details the Killing of Drakeo the Ruler
description: The Los Angeles rapper’s family is suing the promoters of the Once Upon a Time in LA festival, citing negligence in the face of a large gang presence.
content: A wrongful-death lawsuit filed Wednesday in Los Angeles said that negligence and lax security amid a large gang presence at a Live Nation music festival led to the fatal stabbing of the rapper Drakeo the Ruler in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: On English Stages, Tales From the Asylum
description: Two new plays offer very different experiences of the sanitarium, one starring Mark Rylance and the other spotlighting a fast-rising actress.
content: LONDON — “Wash your hands! Wash your hands!” That plea has sounded the world over in recent years, and it lends a topical potency to “Dr. Semmelweis,” running through Feb. 19 at the Bristol Old Vic, a beautiful 18th-century playhouse in southwest England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Breaking Bread’ Review: Peace Meals
description: This documentary follows the preparations for a food festival at which chefs from Arab and Jewish backgrounds team up to create dishes together.
content: “Breaking Bread” opens with a quote from Anthony Bourdain, who said that “food may not be the answer to world peace, but it’s a start.” The premise underlying this documentary, directed by Beth Elise Hawk, is that all cultures can unite over the spectacle of mouthwatering food on camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Krastev
title: Europe Thinks Putin Is Planning Something Even Worse Than War
description: The threat of war could be more destructive than war itself.
content: VIENNA — In the final weeks of World War I, a German general sent a telegram to his Austrian allies summarizing the situation. It was, he wrote, “serious, but not catastrophic.” The reply came back: “Here the situation is catastrophic, but not serious.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lucas Joel
title: Dissolving in Toxic Oceans: How an Ancient Extinction Happened
description: Scientists say rocks on the English coast contain clues of the processes that drove the end-Triassic event that killed as much as a quarter of all life on Earth.
content: Some 200 million years ago, the rocks that became the Palisades cliffs just across the Hudson River from Manhattan formed during volcanic activity that helped rip apart the ancient supercontinent Pangea. That volcanism helped lead to the birth of the Atlantic Ocean while it also contributed to killing off as much as a quarter of all life on Earth during the event known as the end-Triassic mass extinction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Thursday includes figure skating, hockey and curling.
description: Thursday’s schedule includes taped broadcasts of women’s hockey and live coverage of the men’s figure skating team competition, including Nathan Chen for the United States.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Thursday with figure skating, skiing and hockey. All times are in Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends a comedy documentary, a gorgeous Turkish drama and a binge-at-your-own-risk series about motels.
content: ‘(re)Motel’When to watch: Season 2 arrives Friday, on Discovery+.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Lingui, the Sacred Bonds’ Review: Love, Ferocious and Limitless
description: In this electric liberation story from Chad, a mother struggles to protect her daughter’s future and finds both herself and a world of possibility.
content: Freedom doesn’t come easily in “Lingui, the Sacred Bonds,” an electric liberation story about a mother and daughter. It is fought for — and seized — by women who, in saving themselves, save one another. For the daughter, autonomy means securing an abortion in a country that forbids it. For the mother, an observant Muslim, self-sovereignty is a revolutionary act, one that necessitates a shift in thinking and in being. It means saying no, dancing, sneaking smokes and fighting when need be. It means finding new ways to be a woman in this man’s world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Eric Schmitt
title: Who was Abu Ibrahim al-Hashemi al-Qurayshi?
description: Little is known about the ISIS leader, who died, much like his predecessor, in a raid by U.S. commandos in northwestern Syria.
content: The head of Islamic State, Abu Ibrahim al-Hashemi al-Qurayshi, died as he lived most of his life: off the grid in the jihadist underworld.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Brady
description: What information is this graph conveying? Why was it published this week?
content: What information is this graph conveying? It was published on Feb. 2, 2022. How does it relate to or comment on current events? What is your reaction to it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Arnie Kantrowitz, Pioneer of Gay Liberation, Dies at 81
description: A professor, author and activist, he fought against discrimination because of sexual orientation and for fairness from the media.
content: Arnie Kantrowitz, a literature professor and author who was an early champion of gay rights and an indefatigable campaigner for fairer treatment of gay people by the media, died on Jan. 21 at a rehabilitation center in Manhattan. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: The European Central Bank keeps rates steady, despite record inflation.
description: The E.C.B. held to its policy of easing off support for the economy and tolerating record-high inflation in “the interim,” leaving its interest rate untouched.
content: The European Central Bank on Thursday kept to its cautious approach in the face of record inflation in the eurozone, but Christine Lagarde, the bank’s president, acknowledged that “the situation has indeed changed” and refused to rule out a rate increase in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: A deluge of medical waste is swamping the globe, a U.N. report says.
description: Discarded syringes, old test kits and used vaccine vials have strained waste management systems and are threatening people’s health and the environment.
content: A new report from the World Health Organization has highlighted the overabundance of medical waste around the world caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mercedes Lilienthal
title: Worlds Apart, a Friendship Built on Dirt Tracks and 50cc Engines
description: With a motocross mentor from Italy, a teenager from Zimbabwe is chasing her dream in Florida, and lifting girls back home along the way.
content: Stefy Bau got her first dirt bike when she was 4, an Italjet with a 50-cubic-centimeter engine. She was a quick study. “It was at the age of 6 that I started racing,” said Ms. Bau, who is 45 and lived in Turate, Italy, but now calls the open road home as a digital nomad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Michael Gold
title: How the Fallout From Andrew Cuomo’s Resignation Spread to Jeff Zucker
description: Chris Cuomo and Mr. Zucker, the former CNN president, are among those whose careers have suffered in the year since the former governor was first accused of sexual harassment.
content: When former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York was facing a cascade of sexual harassment allegations last year, his instinct was not just to fight but to eviscerate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: “Oh, that Mitzi!” a doctor (Maurice Chevalier) croons in Ernst Lubitsch’s 1932 musical, “One Hour With You,” referring to his wife’s seductive friend (Genevieve Tobin). The film is screening on Friday and Feb. 15 as part of the Museum of Modern Art’s series Dames, Janes, Dolls and Canaries, which runs through Feb. 19. The event is devoted to Mitzi, her fellow vamps and other self-assured female characters of the early 1930s, before the Production Code inhibited American movies. More precisely, the program highlights the actresses who played them — stars like Tobin, Bebe Daniels and Helen Twelvetrees, who did not endure as household names.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: TurboTax will let users deposit tax refunds into crypto accounts.
description: The software company has teamed up with Coinbase to allow users the option to convert their state and federal tax refunds into cryptocurrency.
content: Coinbase is trying to establish itself as a mainstream gateway to the world of cryptocurrency, a place to routinely deposit paychecks, expense reimbursements and tax refunds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: The Year of the Tiger overshadows the Olympic panda.
description: In Beijing, the Lunar New Year has been a bigger preoccupation for many residents, while others have gone back to their hometowns for the holiday.
content: Parks and avenues in Beijing are lined with red Lunar New Year lanterns. Streets are deserted as families gather at home to celebrate the Year of the Tiger. The five-ring symbol of the Olympics and the cuddly panda mascot of the Winter Games are hardly to be seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Exposes What It Says Is Russian Effort to Fabricate Pretext for Invasion
description: Officials said Russia was planning a fake video showing an attack by Ukrainians on Russian territory or Russian speakers in eastern Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States has acquired intelligence about a Russian plan to fabricate a pretext for an invasion of Ukraine using a faked video that would build on recent disinformation campaigns, according to senior administration officials and others briefed on the material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: For Biden and Adams, a Meeting of Like Minds on Gun Crime
description: President Biden’s visit to New York on Thursday is meant to convey his desire to respond to violent crime while guarding against the danger of excess policing.
content: Last summer, Eric Adams declared himself the “face” of the Democratic Party, pre-emptively seizing the national spotlight months before he took office as mayor of New York City. That spotlight fell directly on Mr. Adams on Thursday, as he hosted President Biden for a summit on public safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Art School Looked Like a Lot of Fun In the ’90s
description: A homage to a predigital era has popped up, as a crowdsourced art project that lives, paradoxically, on Instagram.
content: To Matthew Atkatz, the college snapshots he kept in shoe boxes in his closet for years raised a koan-like question: “If they are sitting in a box,” Mr. Atkatz, 46, said, “do they have any meaning?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Rare Champions League Rights Sale Produces Two Winners
description: UEFA awarded its global broadcasting rights to a longtime partner, but granted Relevent, owned by the Miami Dolphins owner Stephen M. Ross, the same deal for the United States.
content: One after another, the executives from some of the world’s biggest sports agencies filed into a basement auditorium at the headquarters of European soccer’s governing body. On their way in, they passed replicas of some of the biggest trophies in the sport, a pointed reminder of why they had traveled to UEFA’s offices on the banks of Lake Geneva to offer large sums of money to some of soccer’s most powerful officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: As Players and Owners Negotiate, Coaches Have to Wait
description: Aaron Boone misses his players. Buck Showalter hasn’t even met his yet. The lockout has the veteran managers in limbo as they await spring training. They may be waiting a while.
content: Not even the coronavirus pandemic kept Aaron Boone away from his players following the postponement of the start of 2020 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Poly Styrene: I Am a Cliché’ Review: An Overdue Close-up
description: In this new documentary, Poly Styrene’s daughter grapples tenderly with the legacy of her punk rock mother.
content: Marianne Joan Elliott-Said found her stage name, Poly Styrene, running her finger through the yellow pages, she says in an on-camera interview circa 1976. The lead singer-songwriter of the British punk band X-Ray Spex and the first woman of color in Britain to front a successful rock band, she looks and sounds impossibly, wonderfully young. She has a mouth full of braces, soft eyes and an open smile. The name appealed because it suggested a kind of plastic, she said. Yet there was little synthetic about the rebellious performer with the startling voice. Nor are there any false notes in “Poly Styrene: I Am a Cliché,” a documentary directed by her daughter, Celeste Bell, and Paul Sng.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muhammad Hij Kadour and Ben Hubbard
title: ‘Those Who Remain Will Die’: Neighbors Recall Night of Fear in Syria Raid
description: In a village in Syria, residents took cover, watched and hid as U.S. forces assaulted the house next door, killing the leader of ISIS.
content: ATMEH, Syria — The neighbors had never heard anything like it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: The coronavirus continues to sideline Olympic athletes as they gear up for competition.
description: Twenty-six new infections were reported as of Thursday, bringing the total number of confirmed positive cases to 287.
content: Coronavirus infections among athletes continue to jeopardize medal hopes in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Natural Gas Shipments, Mostly From U.S., Ease Europe’s Energy Crunch
description: As Russia squeezes supplies, a parade of tankers carrying liquefied natural gas is coming to Europe’s rescue.
content: Near the entrance to Rotterdam’s vast harbor in the Netherlands is a specialized port that is offering an alternative to the web of Russian pipelines that feed much of Europe’s hunger for natural gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Anderson and Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: Sweden says it will end Covid restrictions, joining other European nations.
description: Denmark, Norway and others have also been changing their approaches to the pandemic and scrapping many safety protocols.
content: STOCKHOLM — The Swedish government will lift most Covid restrictions next week, Prime Minister Magdalena Andersson of Sweden announced on Thursday. The move adds Sweden to the growing list of European nations, including Denmark and Norway, that are scrapping pandemic protocols even though new cases continue to soar in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Have You Lost a Loved One During the Pandemic?
description: The Daily wants to honor Americans who have died from the coronavirus.
content: The Daily is working on a special episode memorializing the people we have lost to Covid-19 in the United States. If you have lost someone close to you during the pandemic and would like to share their name with us, please follow the instructions below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: More than 4,600 flights have been canceled nationwide.
description: More than one out of every 10 flights in the United States was affected by the winter weather on Thursday.
content: The winter storm sweeping across much of the United States led to thousands of flight cancellations and delays on Thursday, with many more likely throughout the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Turkey, a Sometimes Wavering NATO Ally, Backs Ukraine
description: In a public rebuke of Russia, Turkey will expand supplies of one of the Ukrainian Army’s most sophisticated weapons, a long-range, Turkish-made armed drone.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey agreed on Thursday to expand supplies of one of the Ukrainian Army’s most sophisticated weapons, a long-range, Turkish-made armed drone whose use in combat for the first time in Ukraine last fall infuriated Russian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: How Malaysia Got in on the Secondhand Clothing Boom
description: Sellers from the country have become a reliable source of sought-after labels, finding high value in discarded items.
content: Maybe it was the pandemic, or growing concerns about the environment, or a bit of both, but one thing’s certain: People are doing a lot more secondhand shopping these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: G.M. workers in Mexico pick an independent union, a trade deal test case.
description: The vote came after the United States, Mexico and Canada revised a trade agreement that sought to strengthen the hand of workers.
content: Workers at one of the largest General Motors plants in Mexico voted to adopt an independent union on Thursday in what was seen as an important test case for whether new North American trade rules can improve working conditions and stamp out corruption in the Mexican labor system.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read Biden’s statement on the ISIS leader’s death.
description: Last night at my direction, U.S. military forces in northwest Syria successfully undertook a counterterrorism operation to protect the American people and our allies, and make the world a safer place. Thanks to the skill and bravery of our armed forces, we have taken off the battlefield Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi — the leader of ISIS. All Americans have returned safely from the operation. I will deliver remarks to the American people later this morning. May God protect our troops.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Jean-Jacques Beineix, ‘Cinema du Look’ Director, Dies at 75
description: His first feature, “Diva,” a visually unusual tale, is credited with starting a new, style-focused genre of filmmaking in France.
content: Jean-Jacques Beineix, a French film director whose debut feature, the eye-popping, droll thriller “Diva,” was much acclaimed, especially outside of France, in the early 1980s and is often credited with starting a genre of French filmmaking known as the cinéma du look, died on Jan. 13 at his home in Paris. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Politics of Redistricting in New York
description: Maps of congressional districts approved by the Democratic-controlled Legislature in Albany could flip as many as three House seats now held by Republicans.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at the plan for redrawing New York State’s congressional districts, a partisan plan approved by the Democratic-controlled Legislature. We’ll also meet people who defend former Gov. Andrew Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: 2 Chainz Is a Dedicated Father With a Competitive Streak
description: The rapper’s list of must-haves revolves around his love of sports and his three kids, although he’s not above teaching them the art of losing.
content: The Atlanta rapper 2 Chainz has lived a lot of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: When Are the Olympics? Here Is the Schedule for Beijing.
description: The opening ceremony will be held on Friday. A few sports start early, but the bulk of the action begins on Saturday. Here’s when to watch what.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: edifice
description: This word has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word edifice has appeared in 51 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 15 in “The Visionary Community of the Harlem Y.M.C.A.” by Sandra E. Garcia:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Alone With You’ Review: An Anniversary for One
description: A woman hoping for a romantic night with her girlfriend instead finds herself trapped in her Brooklyn apartment, facing down demons.
content: In the long history of horror, lesbian relationships have been something of a fixation for directors. That fascination has produced works of camp, wildly homophobic characters and, occasionally, refreshing representation. “Alone With You,” the first feature from the writing-directing duo Emily Bennett and Justin Brooks, is the latest horror film to join this lineage. Unfortunately, its lesbian representation is so shoddy that its scares also suffer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: 6 Reasons Meta Is in Trouble
description: The company formerly known as Facebook has hit major turbulence as it suffered its biggest one-day wipeout ever.
content: Meta, the company formerly known as Facebook, suffered its biggest one-day wipeout ever on Thursday as its stock plummeted 26 percent and its market value plunged by more than $230 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: January Jobs Report May Disappoint. It Is Sure to Perplex.
description: Omicron’s impact is likely to be reflected unevenly in the data, and normal seasonal patterns may have been upended.
content: The January jobs report is arriving at a critical time for the U.S. economy. Inflation is rising. The pandemic is still taking a toll. And the Federal Reserve is trying to decide how best to steer the economy through a swirl of competing threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj
title: Its Beaches Mired in Crude Oil, Peru Vows to Make Refinery Pay
description: A leak at a refinery tarred miles of Pacific Coast beaches. The company blames waves caused by a distant volcano eruption, but the Peruvian government has vowed to “defend the sea.”
content: LIMA, Peru — More than two weeks after a botched tanker delivery sent thousands of barrels of crude oil spilling into the sea off Peru, black waves are still fouling beaches and fingers are still being pointed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Food Prices Approach Record Highs, Threatening the World’s Poorest
description: The prices have climbed to their highest level since 2011, according to a U.N. index. It could cause social unrest “on a widespread scale,” one expert said.
content: WASHINGTON — Food prices have skyrocketed globally because of disruptions in the global supply chain, adverse weather and rising energy prices, increases that are imposing a heavy burden on poorer people around the world and threatening to stoke social unrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: The U.S. women’s hockey team opens the Games against Finland. Again.
description: For months, most discussions about the Olympic women’s hockey tournament have focused on the prospect of another epic final between the United States and Canada. All the while, one of the Americans’ best players has had her mind on a different game.
content: For months, most discussions about the Olympic women’s hockey tournament have focused on the prospect of another epic final between the United States and Canada. All the while, one of the Americans’ best players has had her mind on a different game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Ben Hubbard
title: Raid Targeting ISIS Leader Came After Months of Planning
description: President Biden said the attack on Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi was designed to minimize civilian casualties, but then the terrorist leader set off a bomb.
content: A risky predawn raid by U.S. Special Operations forces that resulted in the death of the Islamic State’s leader on Thursday was set in motion months ago with a tip that the top terrorist was hiding out on the top floor of a house in northwest Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘The Worst Person in the World’ Review: Oslo, Her Way
description: Renate Reinsve stars in Joachim Trier’s funny-sad story of a woman on the verge of figuring herself out.
content: Who does Julie think she is?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Does Ron DeSantis Really Have a Shot Against Trump?
description: If Trump runs, he’ll effectively have the advantages of an incumbent.
content: In early 2016, as Jeb Bush floundered, the Republican establishment began to throw its support behind a different politician from Florida who seemed as if he could defeat the upstart Donald Trump. Senator Marco Rubio was 44 and handsome, and had put together a somewhat impressive legislative record during his five years in office. National Review called Rubio a “Republican dream” and hedge fund managers were donating millions to his campaign. Trump led comfortably in the polls, but it was still early, as G.O.P. insiders reminded us, and they still hadn’t put their thumbs fully on the scale. We all know how the story ends: Rubio wasn’t able to mount any sort of credible challenge to Trump and withdrew after just a few months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: A Struggling San Francisco Art School Will Merge With a University
description: The San Francisco Art Institute, which has been plagued by crippling debt, has formalized plans to integrate with — and eventually be acquired by — the University of San Francisco.
content: Leaders of the financially troubled San Francisco Art Institute say they have formalized plans to integrate operations and academic programs with the University of San Francisco, a private Jesuit university, in a process they say will eventually lead to the university acquiring the 150-year-old art school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Meta’s ‘Unmitigated Disaster’ of a Quarter
description: Mark Zuckerberg delivered bad news for shareholders of Facebook’s parent company.
content: Lately, Mark Zuckerberg has been redirecting investors’ attention away from Facebook’s existing social media platforms and toward the exciting future of virtual worlds in the metaverse. (The company is now called Meta, after all.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Shakespearean Fool
description: Were you bamboozled by Adam Wagner’s puzzle?
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Whenever a puzzle with this sort of theme is published, I try to preface my column by saying something like: “It’s not you. It’s the puzzle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Austria’s sweeping Covid vaccine mandate is becoming law.
description: The measure requires almost everyone 18 or over to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, a wider-ranging mandate than any other European country has yet imposed.
content: Austria is the first Western democracy to mandate Covid vaccinations for nearly its entire adult population, a once-unthinkable move that is being seen as a test case for other countries grappling with pockets of vaccine resistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: ‘Daddy, What’s an Originalist?’

author: By Amanda Hess
title: Apocalypse When? Global Warming’s Endless Scroll
description: From “Don’t Look Up” to Greta Thunberg videos to doomsaying memes, we are awash in warnings that we are almost out of time. But the climate crisis is outpacing our emotional capacity to describe it.
content: I can’t say precisely when the end began, just that in the past several years, “the end of the world” stopped referring to a future cataclysmic event and started to describe our present situation. Across the ironized hellscape of the internet, we began “tweeting through the apocalypse” and blogging the Golden Globes ceremony “during the end times” and streaming “Emily in Paris” “at the end of the world.” Often the features of our dystopia are itemized, as if we are briskly touring the concentric circles of hell — rising inequality, declining democracy, unending pandemic, the financial system optimistically described as “late” capitalism — until we have reached the inferno’s toasty center, which is the destruction of the Earth through man-made global warming.

content: Sometimes, I watch a reality TV show called “Building Off the Grid,” about people who decide to make homes for themselves in remote places where they can live sustainable lives. Over the course of an hour, I’ll watch someone build a yurt or a mud hut with cob walls or a house on a mountain outside of Denver, powered by solar panels. It’s clear that what these modern-day hermits want is to exist in a vacuum, where they are not affected by nor do they affect anything beyond the boundaries of their home. That is, certainly, an illusion, but I can see the appeal.

Following India’s independence from colonial Britain and the bloody Partition that accompanied it, the creation of Pakistan incited one of the largest mass migrations in history across the region, and beyond.
